importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the start of Nicolas Sarkozy's five-year jail sentence, making it a pivotal moment in French political history.
The day of sentencing and imprisonment is significant as it represents the first time a former head of a European Union state has been jailed.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The two-month period during which the court will examine the appeal for Sarkozy’s release is a critical legal window in the case.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's former president, began serving a five-year jail sentence in Paris on October 21, 2025, becoming the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned.
Sarkozy was convicted of criminal conspiracy for accepting millions of euros from Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 election campaign, despite consistently denying the charges.
The presiding judge, Nathalie Gavarino, stated the offences were of 'exceptional gravity,' justifying the sentence even if an appeal is filed.
Sarkozy will be held in solitary confinement in a nine-square-metre cell at La Sante prison, with one daily walk and three weekly visits.
His lawyers immediately filed an appeal for his release, and the court has two months to review it.
Sarkozy is the first French leader to be imprisoned since Philippe Petain, a WWII collaborationist, who was jailed after the war.
Sarkozy expressed that he is an innocent man, stating, 'It is not a former president of the republic being jailed this morning, but an innocent man,' and said truth will prevail.
Public support was strong, with dozens of supporters and family members gathering outside his home, singing the French national anthem and chanting 'Free Nicolas.'

summaryOfNewsArticle: France’s former president Nicolas Sarkozy began serving a five-year jail sentence at La Sante prison on October 21, 2025, becoming the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned. The sentence stems from a conviction of criminal conspiracy for accepting millions of euros from Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 election campaign, a claim he has consistently denied. Presiding judge Nathalie Gavarino described the crimes as of 'exceptional gravity,' justifying the sentence even if an appeal is filed. Sarkozy will be held in solitary confinement in a nine-square-metre cell with limited contact, and his lawyers have immediately filed a release appeal, which the court will review within two months. The case has sparked significant public emotion, with supporters gathering outside his home to demand his freedom, and it marks a rare moment in French political history as the first French leader since WWII collaborationist Philippe Petain to be imprisoned.
title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy starts five-year jail term
